rules: Rule1: If the game is criticized, then the game is not popular.
Rule2: Under the condition that the game uses the PC platform, the game has a story‑driven campaign.
Rule3: When the game uses the console platform, it follows that if the project is not greenlit, then the game has multiplayer.
Rule4: The game uses PBR material or the game uses voxel material.

Rule5: If the game uses voxel material, then, assuming that it is false that (if the game does not use the PC platform and does not use the console platform, then the game is cross‑platform), the game does not have server issues.
Rule6: Either the project has a high budget or, in the event that the project is not greenlit, the game uses the Unreal Engine.

Rule7: The game has mod support, or, should the game use PBR material, then if it is not true that (when the game does not use the PC platform or the console platform, the game is cross‑platform), the game does not have server issues.
Rule8: Provided that the game simulates weather, then if the project is not greenlit, the game has VR support.
Rule9: If the game simulates a day‑night cycle, then the game simulates weather.
Rule10: Either the launch event is successful or the game simulates a day‑night cycle.
Rule11: Should the game have a day‑one patch, then the launch event is not successful.
Rule12: Whenever the game has a post‑launch patch, the launch event is not successful.
Rule13: If the game is reviewed positively, then the game has a day‑one patch.
Rule14: The game is reviewed positively or the game is reviewed mixed.
Rule15: The project is cancelled or the project is greenlit.
Rule16: If the project has an experienced team, then the project has a large team.
Rule17: Under the condition that the engine has proprietary tools, the project has a large team.
Rule18: If the engine has a licensing issue, then the engine is open source.
Rule19: Whenever the engine has a licensing issue, the engine is not open source.
Rule20: The project has a publisher backer or the project has a crowdfunding backer.
Rule21: If the project has a crowdfunding backer, then the project is not cancelled.
Rule22: The game enters beta or the game enters alpha.
Rule23: Under the condition that the game enters alpha, then, provided that it is false that (if the project has a publisher backer, the project is not cancelled), the project meets a milestone.
Rule24: If the game receives positive feedback, then the game fixes bugs.
Rule25: The game receives positive feedback or the game receives negative feedback.

Rule26: Under the condition that the game receives negative feedback, then, should the game enter beta, if it is not true that (when the project has a publisher backer, the project is not cancelled), the project meets a milestone.

Rule27: Whenever the game adjusts balance, then, if the game enters beta, provided that it is not the case that (when the project has a publisher backer, the project is not cancelled), the project meets a milestone.
Rule28: If the game fixes bugs, then the game adjusts balance.

Rule29: Provided that the game uses advanced AI, then, if it is not true that (when the project does not have a tight deadline or does not have a high budget, the game does not have a critical bug), the release is not delayed.
Rule30: The game uses advanced AI or the game uses realistic physics.

Rule31: Should the game use realistic physics, then, assuming that it is false that (if the project does not have a tight deadline or does not have a high budget, then the game does not have a critical bug), the release is not delayed.
Rule32: If the game has microtransactions, then the game is popular.
Rule33: Provided that the game has microtransactions, the game is criticized.
Rule34: Should it be false that (if the game is reviewed mixed, then the game has a post‑launch patch), then the game wins an award.
Rule35: If it is not the case that (when the game is reviewed mixed, the game has a post‑launch patch), then the game does not win an award.
Rule36: Provided that it is not true that (the project has a tight deadline or the project does not have a high budget), then the game has a critical bug.
Rule37: Provided that it is not true that (if the project has secure funding, then the project is not cancelled), the project has an experienced team.
Rule38: Should it be false that (if the project has secure funding, then the project is not cancelled), then the game uses a custom engine.
Rule39: Whenever it is not true that (when the project has secure funding, the project is not cancelled), the project does not have a large team.
Rule40: If it is not the case that (when the game uses a custom engine, the engine has proprietary tools), then the engine has a licensing issue.
Rule41: If it is not true that (when the game does not use the PC platform or the console platform, the game is cross‑platform), then the game has server issues.
Rule42: Should it be not the case that (when the project does not have a tight deadline or does not have a high budget, the game does not have a critical bug), then the release is delayed.
Rule43: If it is not true that (when the project is not greenlit, the game is not released), then the game has microtransactions.
Rule44: If the project is not greenlit, then the game is released.
Rule45: Under the condition that the project is not greenlit, the game does not use the Unreal Engine.
Rule46: Should the project not be greenlit, the game does not have VR support.
facts: Fact1: The project has secure funding.
Fact2: The game does not have multiplayer.
Fact3: The game does not have a story‑driven campaign.
Fact4: The game is not cross‑platform.
Fact5: The game does not have mod support.
Fact6: The project does not have a tight deadline.
Fact7: The project does not meet a milestone.
